articles.title: Ticketless train travel to be trialled across cities
articles.summary: The digital ticketing trials will allow passengers to check in and out using a location-identifying app.
articles.content:
Ticketless train travel to be trialled across cities

2 hours ago Share Save Isaac Ashe BBC News, Derby Share Save

BBC Passengers in the East Midlands will be the first to test the ticketing technology

Ticketless train travel that works by tracking passengers' locations is being trialled in the East Midlands. The location-based technology will be tested by East Midlands Railway (EMR) from Monday, by up to 1,000 people travelling through Derby, Leicester, Nottingham and the stations in between. The app promises to automatically charge these passengers "the best fare at the end of the day". Further 1,000-person trials will take place on three services run by rail operator Northern in Yorkshire from the end of September, the Department for Transport said.

The digital ticketing uses global positioning system (GPS) tracking on users' mobile phones to automatically charge passengers the best overall fare at the end of the day, including on CrossCountry as well as EMR. If multiple journeys are made, the government said it would calculate if a season ticket would have been cheaper. For ticket inspections and to pass through barriers, the app will generate a bar code to scan. Passengers can sign up to the trial, called Digital Pay As You Go, through EMR's website.

'Long overdue'

EMR head of commercial strategy and business planning Oli Cox said more than 500 people had already signed up. He said "complex" fares were sometimes "a real barrier" for passengers and added: "This trial removes that uncertainty, making it easy to simply tap in and out on your phone, safe in the knowledge you're always getting the best-value fare on the day." EMR added the trial would not affect the decision to install ticket barriers limiting access to platforms from the footbridge through Nottingham railway station. Trials will begin running on Northern services between Harrogate, Leeds, Sheffield, Doncaster and Barnsley at the end of the month. The EMR and Northern trials will run for nine months and have been given £1m of government funding as part of its Plan for Change. Rail minister Lord Peter Hendy said testing ticketless travel should save passengers both time and money. He said: "The railway ticketing system is far too complicated and long overdue an upgrade to bring it into the 21st Century."
articles.reasoning: The article describes a government-backed trial of a digital ticketing system using GPS technology that simplifies train travel fare calculation and promises cost savings and convenience for a broad public audience. This innovation has clear positive real-world impact by reducing complexity and potentially saving time and money for many passengers, with a well-defined scope and sufficient detail about the trial and technology.
articles.personality_title: New ticketless train travel trial aims to make journeys simpler and cheaper
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Train tickets can be confusing and costly, with many different prices and options. The UK government wants to make buying train tickets easier and fairer for passengers.

**What happened** – Starting soon, up to 1,000 people in the East Midlands will test a new app that uses GPS on their phones to track train journeys without needing paper tickets. The app automatically finds the best price and charges passengers at the end of the day. Similar tests will happen in Yorkshire later this year.

**Impact** – This trial could remove the stress of choosing the right ticket and save money by checking if a season ticket would be cheaper. Passengers only need to tap in and out with their phones, making travel faster and simpler. The app also creates bar codes for checking tickets and passing through station barriers.

**What's next step** – The trial will last nine months and is supported by £1 million from the government. If successful, this digital ticketing system could be used more widely across the UK, changing how people buy train tickets.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new app trial uses phone GPS to simplify train ticket buying, aiming to save passengers time and money by automatically charging the best fare.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un essai de voyage en train sans billet pour simplifier les trajets et réduire les coûts
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les billets de train peuvent être compliqués et chers, avec de nombreuses options différentes. Le gouvernement britannique souhaite faciliter et rendre plus juste l'achat des billets pour les passagers.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Bientôt, jusqu'à 1 000 personnes dans les East Midlands testeront une nouvelle application qui utilise le GPS de leur téléphone pour suivre les trajets en train sans billet papier. L'application trouve automatiquement le meilleur prix et facture les passagers à la fin de la journée. Des tests similaires auront lieu dans le Yorkshire plus tard cette année.

**Impact** – Cet essai pourrait supprimer le stress de choisir le bon billet et faire économiser de l'argent en vérifiant si un abonnement serait moins cher. Les passagers n'ont qu'à utiliser leur téléphone pour entrer et sortir, ce qui rend les déplacements plus rapides et simples. L'application crée aussi des codes-barres pour les contrôles de billets et les barrières en gare.

**Prochaine étape** – L'essai durera neuf mois et bénéficie d'un financement de 1 million de livres du gouvernement. En cas de succès, ce système de billetterie numérique pourrait être utilisé plus largement au Royaume-Uni, changeant la façon dont les gens achètent leurs billets de train.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une nouvelle application utilisant le GPS du téléphone simplifie l'achat de billets de train en facturant automatiquement le meilleur tarif pour économiser temps et argent.
articles.personality_title_es: Prueba de viajes en tren sin billete para facilitar los trayectos y ahorrar dinero
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los billetes de tren pueden ser confusos y caros, con muchas opciones diferentes. El gobierno del Reino Unido quiere hacer que comprar billetes sea más fácil y justo para los pasajeros.

**Qué pasó** – Pronto, hasta 1,000 personas en East Midlands probarán una nueva aplicación que usa el GPS de sus teléfonos para seguir los viajes en tren sin billetes de papel. La aplicación encuentra automáticamente el mejor precio y cobra a los pasajeros al final del día. Pruebas similares se harán en Yorkshire más adelante este año.

**Impacto** – Esta prueba podría eliminar el estrés de elegir el billete correcto y ahorrar dinero al verificar si un abono sería más barato. Los pasajeros solo necesitan usar su teléfono para entrar y salir, haciendo el viaje más rápido y simple. La aplicación también crea códigos de barras para el control de billetes y el paso por barreras.

**Próximo paso** – La prueba durará nueve meses y cuenta con 1 millón de libras del gobierno. Si tiene éxito, este sistema digital podría usarse en todo el Reino Unido, cambiando la forma en que las personas compran billetes de tren.

**Resumen en una frase** – Una nueva aplicación que usa el GPS del teléfono simplifica la compra de billetes de tren al cobrar automáticamente la mejor tarifa, ahorrando tiempo y dinero.
